lesson.name: Lesson 6.7 Teacher Guide: General Strategy for Factoring Polynomials

page.title: 6.7.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
Lesson Narrative

This lesson challenges students to recognize polynomials of many different forms. After assessing the form of the polynomial, and with no other context, students will select an appropriate strategy for factoring the polynomial. They will then implement that strategy by factoring the polynomial down to its fully factored form, where all the factors are prime.

Additionally, students will analyze an expression to determine if it is prime or fully factored, or if it can be factored further.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Analyze a polynomial by its form, select an appropriate strategy for factoring, and correctly factor the polynomial down to its prime factors.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Recognize and use the appropriate method to factor a polynomial completely.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)


TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A10(D) rewrite polynomial expressions of degree one and degree two in equivalent forms using the distributive property;

A10(E) factor, if possible, trinomials with real factors in the form \(ax^2 + bx + c\), including perfect square trinomials of degree two; and

A10(F) decide if a binomial can be written as the difference of two squares and, if possible, use the structure of a difference of two squares to rewrite the binomial.

Full coverage: Lesson provides content that covers all parts of this TEKS.

Full coverage: Lesson provides content that covers all parts of this TEKS.

Full coverage: Lesson provides content that covers all parts of this TEKS.

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 6.7.1: Factoring Strategies for Polynomials
  • 6.7.2: Reviewing General Strategies to Factor a Polynomial
    • 6.7.2: Self Check
    • 6.7.2: Additional Resources
  • 6.7.3: Implementing General Strategies for Factoring
    • 6.7.3: Self Check
    • 6.7.3: Additional Resources
  • 6.7.4: Is the Polynomial Completely Factored?

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 6.7.5: Practice.

Required Materials

  • Pencil and paper

Required Preparation

  • None

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson. Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson:

Previous Vocabulary

New Vocabulary

  • conjugate pair
  • difference of squares
  • binomial
  • trinomial
  • greatest common factor (GCF)
  • factoring
  • none

Support for Building Character

Throughout this unit, find ways to encourage and support students to work on cultivating their judgment.

Here are some tips to try during this lesson:

  • How Did You Do?
  • Through the Eyes of a Child

You can find other tips located here in the Playbook on Judgment from Character Lab.

page.title: 6.7.1: Factoring Strategies for Polynomials
page.contents:
Warm Up (5 minutes)

This warm-up refreshes and reviews all the factoring strategies learned in this unit. Students will remember that each strategy is useful for a specific type of polynomial. In this activity, they will work in pairs to recall the ideal type of polynomial for each strategy learned so far.

Launch

Arrange students in groups of 2. Have each pair of students complete the activity questions together.

Student Activity

  1. Working with a partner, list as many strategies as you can for factoring polynomials.

ANSWER:

  • Factoring by finding the GCF of an expression and using reverse distribution
  • Factoring using grouping
  • Factoring trinomials of the form \(x^2 + bx + c\) (undo FOIL)
  • Factoring trinomials of the form \(ax^2 + bx + c\) using trial and error
  • Factoring trinomials using the “\(ac\)” method
  • Factoring using substitution
  • Factoring the difference of squares
  • Factoring perfect square trinomials
  1. Work with your partner to write a sample polynomial that would be fitting for each strategy listed.

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

ANSWER:

Factoring Strategy

Sample Polynomial

Factoring by finding the GCF of an expression and using reverse distribution

\(14a + 8ab + 12\)

Factoring using grouping

\(x^2 + 2x − 5x − 10\)

Factoring trinomials of the form \(x^2 + bx + c\) (undo FOIL)

\(t^2 + 14t + 24\)

Factoring trinomials of the form \(ax^2 + bx + c\) using trial and error

\(18x^2 − 3xy − 10y^2\)

Factoring trinomials using the “\(ac\)” method

\(16x^2 − 32x + 12\)

Factoring using substitution

\((x−2)^2 + 7(x−2) + 12\)

Factoring the difference of squares

\(81y^2 − 1\)

Factoring perfect square trinomials

\(25v^2 + 20v + 4\)

Activity Synthesis

Ask students:

  • Are there any strategies that you are not sure when to use? Address their questions in regard to when to use any strategies mentioned.
  • Do you have a favorite strategy? Explain. (Sample answer: the “\(ac\)” method because it works on any trinomial of the form \(ax^2 + bx +c\).)
  • Do you have a least favorite strategy? Explain.

page.title: 6.7.2: Reviewing General Strategies to Factor a Polynomial
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

In this activity, students are given polynomials without any additional context. They must choose a strategy to factor them appropriately and defend their choice with reasoning.

Launch

Take 2–3 minutes to review the diagram at the start of the activity as a class. Using the sample polynomial from the table, \(4x^2 + 20xy + 25y^2\), find its correct place in the diagram and corresponding strategy. (perfect square trinomial of the form \(a^2 + 2ab + b^2\))

Allow students 10–12 minutes to complete questions 1–7 individually. Leave 3–5 minutes for students’ questions regarding appropriate strategies.

For an additional challenge, pose the polynomial in Extending Your Thinking. The factored solution requires multiple strategies implemented in the correct order.

Student Activity

Take a moment to look at all parts of the diagram. Are there any parts that you do not understand?

Use this time to ask your teacher if there is something you would like clarified here.

Use the diagram above as needed for the activity.

Determine the best strategy to factor the polynomial. Explain your reasoning. Remember to factor out the GCF first, if necessary, before choosing a strategy. If a polynomial is prime, write “prime.” An example is provided.

Polynomial

Reasoning

Strategy

\(4x^2 + 20xy + 25y^2\)

After GCF, trinomial of form \(a^2 + 2ab + b^2\)

trinomial square pattern

  1. \(8y^3 + 16y^2 − 24y\)

    ANSWER: After GCF, trinomial of form \(x^2+bx+c\); undo FOIL
  1. \(16x^3 − 36x\)

    ANSWER: After GCF, a binomial of squares; difference of squares
  1. \(6pq^2 − 9pq − 6p\)

    ANSWER: After GCF, trinomial of form \(ax^2+bx+c\); “\(ac\)” method or trial and error
  1. \(4x^2 − 12xy + 9y^2 − 25\)

    ANSWER: polynomial of 4 terms; grouping
  1. \(a^2 + 9\)

    ANSWER: no factors; prime
  1. \(9x^2 − 24xy + 16y^2\)

    ANSWER: trinomial of form \(a^2  − 2ab + b^2\); trinomial square pattern
  1. \(27y^2 − 48\)

    ANSWER: After GCF, a binomial of squares; difference of squares

Student Facing Extension

Extending Your Thinking

Factor the polynomial below. Write down every factoring strategy that you use.

\(9x^2 − 12xy + 4y^2 − 49\)

ANSWER: \((3x − 2y −7)(3x − 2y + 7)\); Strategies Used: 

Factor out GCF, grouping, perfect square trinomial, difference of squares

Here is how tto factor this polynomial:

Step 1
Is there a GCF?
\(9x^2−12xy+4y^2−49\)
No.

Step 2
With more than three terms, use grouping. The last two terms have no GCF. Try grouping the first three terms.

Step 3
Factor the trinomial with \(a \neq 1\). But the first term is a perfect square.
Is the last term of the trinomial a perfect square?
\((3x)^2−12xy+(2y)^2−49\)
Yes.

Step 4
Does the trinomial fit the pattern \(a^2 \pm 2ab + b^2\)?
( 3 x ) 2 ↘ −12 x y + −2 ( 3 x ) ( 2 y ) ↙ ( 2 y ) 2 − 49 ( 3 x ) 2 ↘ −12 x y + −2 ( 3 x ) ( 2 y ) ↙ ( 2 y ) 2 − 49
Yes.

Step 5
Write the trinomial as a square.
\((3x−2y)^2−49\)

Step 6
Is this binomial a sum or difference? Of squares or cubes? Write it as a difference of squares.
\((3x−2y)^2−7^2\)

Step 7
Write it as a product of conjugates.
\(((3x−2y)−7)((3x−2y)+7)\)
\((3x−2y −7)(3x−2y +7)\)

Step 8
Is the expression factored completely?
Yes.

Step 9
Check your answer by multiplying.
\((3x−2y−7)(3x−2y+7)\)
\(9x^2−6xy−21x−6xy+4y^2+14y+21x−14y−49\)
\(9x^2−12xy+4y^2−49✓\)

Activity Synthesis

Pose the following questions to students:

  • Which strategy is applicable to factoring binomials? (difference of squares; factoring the GCF)
  • Which strategy is applicable to factoring trinomials of the form \(x^2 + bx +c\)? (undoing FOIL)
  • Which strategy is applicable to factoring trinomials of the form \(ax^2 + bx +c\)? (trial and error, the “\(ac\)” method)
  • Which strategy is applicable to factoring trinomials of the form \(ax^2 \pm 2ab + b^2\)? (perfect square trinomials)
  • Which strategy is applicable to factoring polynomials with \(4\) expressions? (grouping)
  • Which strategy is applicable to polynomials that don’t seem to factor easily? (substitution, grouping, factoring the GCF)

6.7.2: Self Check 

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION:

Which strategy would you use to factor \(40x^2y + 44xy − 24y\)? What is the factored result?

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

Factor out the GCF. Use the undo FOIL method.

\(4y(5x + 2)(2x − 3)\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The GCF is \(4y\). Since the first term of the remaining trinomial does not have a coefficient of \(1\), this is not the best strategy. Use the “\(ac\)” method. The answer is \(4y(5x − 2)(2x + 3)\).

Factor out the GCF. Use the difference of squares.

\(4y(5x − 2)(5x + 2)\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The GCF is \(4y\). The remaining polynomial is a trinomial, and you cannot use the difference of squares. Use the “\(ac\)” method. The answer is \(4y(5x − 2)(2x + 3)\).

Factor out the GCF. Use the “\(ac\)” method.

\(4y(5x − 2)(2x + 3)\)

That’s correct! Check yourself: The GCF is \(4y\). The remaining trinomial has the form \(ax^2 - bx + c\). You can use trial and error or the “\(ac\)” method. 

Factor out the GCF. Use the perfect square trinomial strategy. 

\(4y(5x + 2)(2x − 3)\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The GCF is \(4y\). The remaining trinomial does not have the form \(a^2 + 2ab + b^2\) for that method. Use the “\(ac\)” method. The answer is \(4y(5x − 2)(2x + 3)\).

6.7.2: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Reviewing General Strategies to Factor a Polynomial

You have now become acquainted with all the methods of factoring that you will need in this course. The following chart summarizes all the factoring methods we have covered and outlines a strategy you should use when factoring polynomials.

These are the steps to use when deciding how to factor a polynomial. We will review an example after looking at these steps.


Use a general strategy for factoring polynomials:

Step 1
Is there a greatest common factor? Factor it out.

Step 2
Is the polynomial a binomial, a trinomial, or are there more than three terms?

If it is a binomial:

  • Is it a sum?
    • Of squares? Sums of squares do not factor.
    • Of cubes? Use the sum of cubes pattern.
  • Is it a difference?
    • Of squares? Factor as the product of conjugates.

If it is a trinomial:

  • Is it of the form \(x^2+bx+c\)? Undo FOIL.
  • Is it of the form \(ax^2+bx+c\)?
    • If \(a\) and \(c\) are squares, check if it fits the trinomial square pattern.
    • Use trial and error or the “\(ac\)” method.

If it has more than three terms:

  • Use the grouping method.

Step 3
Check.

  • Is it factored completely?
  • Do the factors multiply back to the original polynomial?

EXAMPLE 1

Factor completely: \(24y^2 − 150\).

Be careful when you are asked to factor a binomial because there are several options!

Step 1
Is there a GCF?
\(24y^2 − 150\)
Yes, \(6\).

Step 2
Factor out the GCF.
\(6(4y^2 − 25)\)

Step 3
In the parentheses, is it a binomial, a trinomial, or are there more than three terms?
Binomial.

Step 4
Is it a sum?
No.

Step 5
Is it a difference? Of squares or cubes?
Yes, squares.
\(6((2y)^2 − (5)^2)\)

Step 6
Write as a product of conjugates.
\( 6(2y − 5)(2y + 5)\)

Step 7
Is the expression factored completely? 
Neither binomial can be factored.

Step 8
Check your answer by multiplying.
\(6(2y − 5)(2y + 5)\)
\(6(4y^2 − 25)\)
\(24y^2 − 150✓\)

EXAMPLE 2

Use the diagram and questions as references. Which strategy would you use to factor the following polynomials in the left column of the table? Explain your reasoning.

Look at each polynomial. Review the steps to decide which strategy to use.

Polynomial

Strategy

Reasoning

\(x^2 − 3x − 10\)

\(4a^2 − 12ab + 9b^2\)

\(4y^2 − 25\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Polynomial

Strategy

Reasoning

\(x^2 − 3x − 10\)

undo FOIL

trinomial of form \(x^2+bx+c\)

\(4a^2 − 12ab + 9b^2\)

trinomial square pattern

trinomial of form \(a^2 − 2ab + b^2\)

\(4y^2 − 25\)

difference of squares

a binomial of squares

Try It: Reviewing General Strategies to Factor a Polynomial

Identify the strategy you would use to factor each polynomial.

  1. \(4x^2y − 16xy + 12y\)
  1. \(4x^2 + 8bx − 4ax − 8ab\)

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to compare your work.

Solution

Often, there will be more than one strategy that can be used to factor a polynomial. Here are some sample solutions.

  1. Factor out the GCF of \(4y\). Use the undo FOIL method on the remaining polynomial since it is of the form \(x^2+bx+c\).
  1. Factor out GCF of \(4\). Then factor by grouping since there are four terms.

page.title: 6.7.3: Implementing General Strategies for Factoring
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

This activity represents the culmination of all of the factoring strategies learned in the unit. Polynomials are given with no context. Students must determine the type of polynomial, choose the correct strategy to implement, and then correctly factor each polynomial.

Launch

Allow students to work with a partner to answer questions 1–7 in the activity. This will encourage discussion and teamwork as they select the correct strategy and factor each polynomial.

Student Activity

Work with a partner on these problems. After each solution, discuss if there are multiple strategies that would work to factor the polynomial.

Find a strategy that fits and factor completely: 

  1. \(5y^3 − 15y^2 − 270y\)

    ANSWER: Factor out GCF of \(5y\). Then use the “undo FOIL” method on the polynomial of the form \(x^2 + bx +c\).
    \( 5y(y − 9)(y + 6)\)
  1. \( 75m^3 + 12m\)

    ANSWER: Factor out GCF of \(3m\).
    \(3m(25m^2 + 4)\)
  1. \(16x^2 + 24xy − 4x − 6y\)

    ANSWER: Factor out GCF of \(2\). Then use the grouping method.
    \(2(4x − 1)(2x + 3y)\)
  1. \(2n^2 + 13n − 7\)

    ANSWER: Use the “\(ac\)” method or trial and error.
    \((2n − 1)(n + 7)\)
  1. \(121r^2 − s^2\)

    ANSWER: Use the difference of squares method.
    \((11r − s)(11r + s)\)
  1. \(25w^2 − 60w + 36\)

    ANSWER: Use the perfect square trinomial method.
    \((5w − 6)^2\)
  1. \((3x + 1)^2 − 6(3x + 1) + 9\)

    ANSWER: Use the substitution or perfect square trinomial method.
    \((3x−2)^2\)
  1. \(16x^2 − 24xy + 9y^2 − 64\).

    ANSWER: Use the grouping method on the first three terms. They are a perfect square trinomial. Then use the difference of squares on the result.
    \((4x − 3y − 8)(4x − 3y + 8)\)

Activity Synthesis

Pose the following question to students:

  • If more than one strategy can be correctly implemented to factor a polynomial, is there an incorrect choice? (As long as you factor a polynomial down to its prime factors, you have correctly factored the polynomial. Sometimes more than one strategy will work.)

Video: Determining Factoring Method

Watch the following video to learn more about how to determine which method of factoring will be best to apply.



6.7.3: Self Check 

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION: 

Which strategy would you use to factor \(9x^2 − 24xy + 16y^2\)? What is the factored result?

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

trinomial square pattern; \((3x + 4y)^2\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The polynomial has the form \(a^2 − 2ab + b^2\). This fits the trinomial square pattern strategy. The signs do not match up with this answer since the second term is negative. The correct answer is \((3x − 4y)^2\).

grouping; \((3x − 4y)(3x + 4y)\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The polynomial has the form \(a^2 − 2ab + b^2\). This fits the trinomial square pattern strategy. Grouping is good when there are more than three terms. The correct answer is \((3x − 4y)^2\).

difference of squares; \((4x − 3y)^2\)

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The polynomial has the form \(a^2 − 2ab + b^2\). This fits the trinomial square pattern strategy. The correct answer is \((3x − 4y)^2\).

trinomial square pattern; \((3x − 4y)^2\)

That’s correct! Check yourself: The polynomial has the form \(a^2 − 2ab + b^2\). Square the factors to check that they are equal to the original polynomial.

6.7.3: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it. 

Implementing General Strategies for Factoring

Let’s practice recognizing and implementing these strategies as we factor polynomials.

Remember, a polynomial is completely factored if, other than monomials, its factors are prime!

EXAMPLE 1

Find a strategy that fits and factor completely: \(7x^3 − 21x^2 − 70x\).

Step 1
Is there a GCF?
\(7x^3 − 21x^2 − 70x\)
Yes, \(7x\).

Step 2
Factor out the GCF.
\(7x(x^2 − 3x − 10)\)

Step 3
In the parentheses, is it a binomial, a trinomial, or are there more than three terms?
Trinomial with leading coefficient \(1\).

Step 4
“Undo” FOIL.
\(7x(x \;\;\; )(x \;\;\; )\)
\(7x(x + 2)(x − 5)\)

Step 5
Is the expression factored completely? 
Yes. Neither binomial can be factored.

Step 6
Check your answer by multiplying.
\(7x(x + 2)(x − 5)\)
\(7x(x^2 − 5x + 2x − 10)\)
\(7x(x^2 − 3x − 10)\)
\(7x^3 − 21x^2 − 70x✓\)

EXAMPLE 2

Find a strategy that fits and factor completely: \(4x^2 + 8bx − 4ax − 8ab\).

Step 1
Is there a GCF?
\(4x^2 + 8bx − 4ax − 8ab\)
Factor out the GCF, \(4\).
\(4(x^2 + 2bx − ax − 2ab)\)

Step 2
There are four terms. Use grouping.
\(4 \lbrack x(x + 2b) − a(x + 2b) \rbrack\)
\(4(x + 2b)(x − a)\)

Step 3
Is the expression factored completely?
Yes.

Step 4
Check your answer by multiplying.
\(4(x + 2b)(x − a)\)
\(4(x^2 − ax + 2bx − 2ab)\)
\(4x^2 + 8bx − 4ax − 8ab✓\)

EXAMPLE 3

Find a strategy that fits and factor completely: \(40x^2y + 44xy − 24y\).

Step 1
Is there a GCF?
\(40x^2y + 44xy − 24y\)
Factor out the GCF, \(4y\).
\(4y(10x^2 + 11x − 6)\)

Step 2
Factor the trinomial with \(a \neq 1\) using the “\(ac\)” method or trial and error.
\(4y(5x − 2)(2x + 3)\)

Step 3
Is the expression factored completely?
Yes.

Step 4
Check your answer by multiplying.
\(4y(5x − 2)(2x + 3)\)
\(4y(10x^2 + 11x − 6)\)
\(40x^2y + 44xy − 24y✓\)

Try It: Implementing General Strategies for Factoring

Find a strategy that fits and factor completely: 

  1. \(27y^2 − 48\)
  1. \(6x^2 − 12xc + 6bx − 12bc\).

Write down your answers. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution

Here is how to factor these polynomials:

  1. difference of squares; \(3(3y − 4)(3y + 4)\)
  1. grouping; \(6(x + b)(x − 2c)\)

page.title: 6.7.4: Is the Polynomial Completely Factored?
page.contents:
Cool Down (5 minutes)

Student Activity

  1. Explain what it means to factor a polynomial completely.

    ANSWER: To factor a polynomial completely means that every factor you have found, or the polynomial itself, is prime.

Determine if each polynomial is completely factored. If the answer is no, write the completely factored form.

  1. \(3x(8x^2 − 9x − 3)\)

    ANSWER: yes
  1. \( 60x^2y − 75xy + 30y\)

    ANSWER: no;
    \(15y(4x^2 − 5x + 2)\)
  1. \(2c(4c^2 + 20cd + 81d^2)\)

    ANSWER: yes
  1. \(5n^2 + 5n + 12\)

    ANSWER: yes
  1. \(5q^2 − 15q − 90\)

    ANSWER: no;
    \(5(q + 3)(q − 6)\)
  1. \(64x^2 + 16xy + y^2\)

    ANSWER: no;
    \((8x + y)^2\)

page.title: 6.7.6: Lesson Synthesis
page.contents:
To summarize the key concepts from the lesson, pose these sample questions again to see if students have learned all of these situations:

  • Which strategy is applicable to factoring binomials? (difference of squares; factoring the GCF)
  • Which strategy is applicable to factoring trinomials of the form \(x^2 + bx +c\)? (undoing FOIL)
  • Which strategy is applicable to factoring trinomials of the form \(ax^2 + bx +c\)? (trial and error, the “\(ac\)” method)
  • Which strategy is applicable to factoring trinomials of the form \(ax^2 \pm 2ab + b^2\)? (perfect square trinomials)
  • Which strategy is applicable to factoring polynomials with 4 expressions? (grouping)
  • Which strategy is applicable to polynomials that don’t seem to factor easily? (substitution, grouping, factoring the GCF)
